title: Will open source kill Microsoft? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. Open Source is a lie, that has strung people along for over a decade. Look at the valuations for supposedly ‘open source’ organization, and you’ll see they are worth millions. There are no programmers, working under a bridge for no pay, altruistically giving away their code and skills for nothing. Programmers get paid, ad they get paid a lot of money. Those multi billion dollar companies using ‘open source’ are bespoking these systems for their own needs, but no one is getting anything for free. There are thousands of versions of Linux type operating systems, all largely incompatible with each other - which is what you’d expect to happen. Organizations like redhat are multi billion dollar organizations because no one uses something without support. Microsoft simply charge a fee and provide free support. These other companies supply an OS for free and charge for support. Open source is not naturally better. Large orgs like Google do it, because they’re not software companies. Google are an advertising company. They buy technology that assures products ‘you and I’ are focussed on their systems. We use google search to find a coffee shop, google maps to get there, google pay to pay for it and then download and play a game from a google app store on a google chrome browser on a google android device. Was the map or search open source? Of course not. Were the apps on the app store open source? Of course not. The things that google open sourced, were the things that maintained its control. The operating system and the browser. The sooner people wake up to this, the better.

No, I expect the opposite. Microsoft is releasing various products as open source these days. These use a special Microsoft license that is incompatible with the GPL. Which is a smart move by Microsoft. Once they release their code with their license, any derivative work will fall under this license also, and just this license. Sublicensing is not allowed! But their license also allows you to publish your work as closed-source, making it interesting for many companies also. They can build upon the free Microsoft libraries without the need to share. Right now, two main products have become very important. First of all the .NET Core framework, which is open source and provides an extremely rich programming environment. Mostly for web development but version 3 is also supporting GUI applications on Windows. It might not take long before they will also support other platforms. These will be Android and iOS at first, MacOS and several BSD versions. And perhaps even Linux. But Linux is challenging because of the GPL. But the GPL does allow dual-licensing, meaning that you can use a second license with GPL if this is more open. And Microsoft’s license is exactly that! So they will build on Linux using a dual license and build on top of this with just their own license. After all, that’s what Google has done with Android… Google made a closed-source environment on top of a GPL-enforced open source layer. Microsoft has never been opposed to open source. But like many, they have been opposed to the restrictions of the GPL. But Microsoft is embracing open source even more than ever before and because their license is not as restrictive as the GPL, it will be very welcome in the developers world. It is possible that Microsoft will actually kill the GPL instead…

Imagine asking tens of millions of workers to switch from Microsoft (kind of standard, despite them mucking with the interfaces) applications to, say, Libre Office. Chaos would ensue, even though the applications do the same thing functionally and are intentionally very similar. People suck at change - especially when they’ve been “doing it this way for 20 years.” Microsoft essentially owns the corporate market and, when they go home, many people (myself included) like to mostly stick with what they’ve been using for the last 10 hours. Because it’s comfortable. That’s how MS got big in the first place.

Open source has been around for a while. If it was going to kill Microsoft, it probably would have by now. Interestingly, Microsoft seems to be embracing open source lately- a big turnaround from their past position on it.
Open source has been going strong now for quite some time. If the goal was to kill Microsoft then it’s doing a shitty job.
